answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Frank – I hope the following is helpful:
Idaho Department of Environmental Quality – Alternative Transportation Incentives
http://www.deq.idaho.gov/media/414529-alternative_transportation_incentives_fs.pdf 
Annapolis – Park N Shop
http://parkannapolis.com/parknshop.shtml 
UC Irvine - Faculty/Staff Incentives
http://www.parking.uci.edu/at/incentives/employee.cfm 
City Considering Parking Incentives 
http://articles.courant.com/2010-10-11/community/hc-hartford-parking-1011-20101011_1_free-parking-morgan-street-garage-parking-days 
San Jose – DOWNTOWN BUSINESS PARKING INCENTIVES
http://sjdowntownparking.com/wpsite/wp-content/uploads/DT-Business-Parking-IncentivesDec142012.pdf 
Green Plus – Alternative Transportation
http://gogreenplus.org/nuts-and-bolts-guide/planet-nuts-and-bolts-guide/transportation/alternative-transportation/ 
Decatur GA - Marketing & Education Initiatives for Encouraging Alternative Transportation Use in Decatur
http://www.decaturga.com/Modules/ShowDocument.aspx?documentid=1217 
Incentives eyed to boost use of alternative transportation in Chattanooga
http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2012/dec/10/green-trips-Incentives-eyed-to-boost-use-of-altern/ 
Pam
Pamela Muse

answers.author: Charles DeBow
answers.text:
Frank- The incentives are the "carrot" and most times you need some "stick" to get the results you want when it comes to getting people to park in the right place.  Educating the business owners on the value of having the most proximate parking spaces for their customers works, but it can be difficult.  Have you considered time limits or ordinances requiring employees to park in the remote areas? 
Do you currently have paid parking in any area? Meters? 
Unfortunately there is no simple answer and the best scenario is probably a mixture of paid parking, time limits and incentives. 
Feel free to contact me if you want to chat about this more.

author: Frank Lancaster
text:
Our community, Estes Park Colorado, is a destination resort in the Colorado mountains.  Our visitation populations soars in the summertime and parking is a major issue.  Part of the issue comes from employees of businesses downtown, and town employees (Town Hall is in the core downtown) parking when they come to work.   We have remote parking areas available.
I'd like to hear from any communities that have had success with incentive programs to encourage folks to use alternative transportation or to park in more remote areas, so the prime parking spaces in the downtown area are available for shoppers and visitors.
Frank Lancaster
Estes Park Colorado
title: Incentives to encourage people to not park downtown
